thread.title: Enderby based Next reveals biggest risk to business in case of no-deal Brexit - Leicestershire Live

author: Leicestershire Live
title: Enderby based Next reveals biggest risk to business in case of no-deal Brexit - Leicestershire Live
text:

Enderby-based retail giant Next PLC has warned over the threat of port delays and increased tariffs from a no-deal Brexit as it outlined contingency plans for the UK quitting the EU without an agreement in place.
The high street chain - led by chief executive and Tory peer Lord Simon Wolfson - said it was "well advanced" in its preparations in case a free-trade agreement is not in place by next March.
It warned the biggest risk to the business was the likelihood of queues and delays at UK and EU ports , while it added that a sharp fall in the value of the pound and increased tariffs also posed a threat. What would happen if there's a no-deal Brexit?
The Leicestershire business said in the "unlikely event" that free-trade agreements were not put in place, it could send the cost of goods soaring by up to around £20 million, which would add almost 0.5 per cent to its prices.
But it said the no-deal risks do not pose a "material threat to the ongoing operations and profitability" of Next in the UK or EU.
Details of its no-deal plans came as it upped its full-year profit outlook after a better-than-expected first half, with interim pre-tax profits up 0.5 per cent at £311.1 million in the six months to July.
It has managed to avoid many of the problems faced by other high street retailers such as House of Fraser, Debenhams and Poundworld, mainly thanks to its strong online operation Next Directory.
And while profits at Next remain steady, by comparison John Lewis recently announced its profits had fallen to almost zero in the first half of the year, partly down to its policy of price matching against rivals. Read More
